messages.content: If I have 50 ml of 8% acid how much water should I add to make 2%

To dilute a solution to a lower concentration, you can add a solvent (in this case, water). In your situation, you're starting with 50 ml of an 8% acid solution and want to dilute it to a 2% solution.

The amount of acid in the original solution stays the same even when you add water. So the volume of the new solution should be 4 times the original volume because 8% divided by 2% is 4.

50 ml * 4 = 200 ml

This means you need a total of 200 ml of solution to achieve a 2% concentration.

Since you already have 50 ml of solution, you should add:

200 ml - 50 ml = 150 ml

So, you need to add 150 ml of water to your 50 ml of 8% acid to get a 2% acid solution.
I put 100ml of 8% acid and now added an additional 100ml of water what percent solution acid do I have?

The amount of acid remains the same when you add water, you just have a larger volume of solution.

You initially had 100 ml of 8% acid solution, which means you had 8 ml of pure acid (100 ml * 8% = 8 ml).

Now, after adding 100 ml of water, you have 200 ml of solution (100 ml of 8% acid solution + 100 ml of water).

The new percentage of acid is calculated as follows:

(8 ml of acid / 200 ml of total solution) * 100% = 4%

So, you now have a 4% acid solution.
I added another 300 ml of water

If you added another 300 ml of water to your 200 ml solution (which was 4% acid), you now have a total of 500 ml of solution (200 ml of 4% acid solution + 300 ml of water).

The amount of acid remains the same, which is 8 ml (from your original 100 ml of 8% acid solution).

To find the new percentage, we calculate it the same way:

(8 ml of acid / 500 ml of total solution) * 100% = 1.6%

So, after adding an additional 300 ml of water, you now have a 1.6% acid solution.
